Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Consortium at the 2018 International Symposium on Experimental Robotics (ISER 2018)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will provide travel funds for 15-20 US-based students to attend the 2018 International Symposium on Experimental Robotics (ISER) in Buenos Aires, Nov 5-8, 2018, and participate in the doctoral consortium. The symposium features both invited and selected research presentations that focus on robotics research that has been validated through experimental results. This unique conference presents the latest advances across various fields of robotics, with ideas that are not only conceived conceptually but also explored experimentally. It has a high visibility in the international robotics research community as well as a high relevance to applications due to its emphasis on experimental validation. ISER 2018 will provide excellent opportunities for students to learn about the latest advances across a wide spectrum of robotics research, development, and applications and to network with seasoned researchers and practitioners in the worldwide robotics community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project supported a doctoral consortium at the 2018 International Symposium on Experimental Robotics (ISER 2018), held in Buenos Aires, Argentina. The grant partially funded 17 US-based PhD student authors to travel to ISER 2018 in Argentina and benefit from the symposium, who otherwise would have been much less likely to attend ISER 2018. Through the organized round-table discussions of the doctoral consortium every day at lunch time, the student awardees were enlightened about robotics research topics as well as aspects of different career paths. Multiple round-table discussions were held simultaneously evey day during the symposium. Each table was assigned 1-2 senior researchers as mentors to hold discussions with student awardees and other participants on a wide range of topics about research and career development. At the end of each lunch, a student awardee from each table would present a summary of the discussion at his/her table to all the symposium participants so that everyone could learn what was discussed at the other tables.The student awardees also had plenty of opportunities to network with senior researchers and each other during the symposium. For many of them, it was their first time to attend an international conference in robotics, and they found the experiance very useful.
